9.64.text: An island enveloped in mist receives the new day, south of the continent of Asia.

14.40.text: This is just one of the over 20,000 islands stretching from Asia to Australia,

20.84.text: but in its interior it holds zoological mysteries which have astonished scientists for generations.

33.92.text: When the first European explorers came to the Indonesia archipelago, at the start of the sixteenth century,

39.80.text: they could hardly believe their eyes: here, before them, lay a new world of impenetrable jungles and erupting volcanoes.

49.20.text: A world of darkness and mystery.

61.28.text: Nature seemed to have lost her senses in this distant land.

66.00.text: Here, they found plants that fed on animals, and fish able to remain out of the water, without perishing,

72.36.text: Each fresh discovery brought a new mystery.

84.92.text: Three hundred years later, at the start of the twentieth century,

89.44.text: a pilot whose plane had crashed into the sea managed to swim ashore on one of these islands.

94.20.text: When the rescue team managed to find him, the man appeared to have lost his senses.

100.60.text: Delirious, he claimed that the island was inhabited by gigantic lizards which, devoured the natives.

107.96.text: Without realising it, those men had ventured into the land of dragons.

136.12.text: During the glaciations of the Pleistocene era, the polar icecaps increased in size, and the level of the sea fell.

144.68.text: Some island remained isolated, while others became joined to the continent. Java was one of these.

160.00.text: Once the glaciation was over, the sea returned to its original level, and Java once more became an island, cut off from mainland Asia.

168.52.text: From that time on, its fauna and flora took different evolutionary roads from those of the continent.

175.56.text: Roads which would lead to the creation of legendary creatures.

190.28.text: Its isolation, and the inaccessibility of its jungles shrouded the island in mystery.

197.44.text: The rare visitors from the continent returned with strange stories telling of unfamiliar animals.

203.84.text: The tales spread, were modified and exaggerated, and by the time they reached distant Europe,

212.44.text: they had become fabulous legends of mythological creatures

223.12.text: Centuries later, when the European colonisers landed on the distant island of Java,

227.72.text: they discovered these strange creatures which had inspired the ancient legends.

245.72.text: Human beings already lived here in the Neolithic period, over 4,000 years ago. And their descendents live there still.

266.04.text: Over many generations, the local people learnt to live with the jungle and its mysterious inhabitants.

272.48.text: They introduced cattle rearing, cut down trees, planted crops and hunted.

277.60.text: Still today they retain a way of life and traditions similar to those witnessed by the first Westerners to arrive in these lands.

300.24.text: Knowledge was handed down from father to son through the oral tradition.

304.80.text: The new generations learnt from their elders which plants to cultivate and with which techniques,

310.08.text: which were the best pastures and which fish were edible.

324.36.text: Along with this knowledge, they also had to learn to fear their predators

328.04.text: and recognise the innumerable dangers of the jungles which surrounded them.

340.36.text: From them, the European explorers received the first descriptions of the fauna of the area.

345.16.text: The visitors’ lack of scientific knowledge would transform these explanations into fabulous tales.

351.20.text: It would seem the most fantastic creatures dwelled in the heart of the jungle.

369.96.text: The majority of these animals lived in the most extensive of the ecosystems of the island  tropical rainforest.

382.00.text: The tree cover is so dense that in some parts barely 5% of the sunlight reaches the ground.

388.12.text: The darkness and the thick vegetation make it almost impossible to spot the animals.

393.52.text: The only signs of their presence are the sounds which fill the air.

408.56.text: It is impenetrable jungle, in which the trees acquire strange shapes, and animals remain hidden to the human eye.

417.20.text: The colonisers were in no doubt: this must be the dwelling place of those animals spoken of in legend.

432.40.text: At all levels of the jungle, the fauna seems invisible, but it is there.

437.44.text: Down on the ground, thousands of tiny animals clean the jungle of corpses and vegetable remains.

443.40.text: Their work is often overlooked, but it vital for the system.

458.76.text: The zoological order of insects is the most numerous in the rainforest.

462.84.text: It is also one of the least well-known: thousands of species living here have not yet been discovered or catalogued by man.

478.80.text: Much of the local fauna can be found up in the trees.

483.36.text: These crab-eating macaques are just one of the ten species of macaques that live in the archipelago.

488.96.text: There are 31 species of primates alone, of which 23 are endemic, that is, exclusive to these islands.

506.68.text: Isolation gave rise to many endemic species, and incredible biological diversity.

512.08.text: Here, we can find tropical rainforests, mangrove swamp, and savanna.

517.08.text: Each one has its own particular fauna and flora.

520.20.text: In some cases, the species are exclusive to the archipelago, or may be even be restricted to a single island.

536.48.text: On other occasions, they are varieties which can also be found in Asia or Australia,

542.64.text: the two continents with which the islands of Indonesia came into contact.

545.84.text: This is the case of the second largest bovine in the world, the banteng.

558.28.text: The banteng, weighing 900 kg. and almost 2 metres high, prefers the open spaces to the interior of the jungle.

565.60.text: There, they find pasture, and have greater possibilities of detecting potential enemies.

570.80.text: Their size is only surpassed by one other bovine, the Indian gaur,

576.20.text: which can weigh up to a tonne, and stands some 30 centimetres higher.

592.32.text: Groups of bantengs are composed of a number of females, led by a dominant male,

598.56.text: who constantly watches over his harem.

609.04.text: In the ancient past, they could be found throughout continental south-east Asia.

614.04.text: They were an important source of food for the local population, and are today domesticated on some islands.

620.20.text: The wild banteng, however, has been hunted intensively and now only survives in Burma, Thailand, Borneo, and here, in Java.

643.36.text: Unlike man, few predators would even attempt to fell a prey of this size.

648.16.text: Their main enemy lies hidden in the depths of the jungle, where it is virtually invisible.

654.16.text: It is the largest predator on the island, an animal feared and venerated by man since ancient times

673.72.text: Today the banteng almost never comes in contact with a tiger.

677.04.text: As a result of the intensive hunting they have been subjected to,

680.68.text: the population has shrunk to such an extent that, in Java, they are virtually certain to become extinct.

687.40.text: This same threat hangs over the largest inhabitant of these jungles.

697.04.text: It was precisely on this island, Java, that the first explorers found one of the most mysterious animals of the archipelago.

703.68.text: The natives described it as a being of prehistoric appearance, with a single horn, like that of the legendary unicorn.

712.00.text: The animal lived inside the jungle, which made it difficult to find.

718.20.text: For a while, the only proof of its existence were the local stories,

724.00.text: strange piles of excrement which appeared in different places within the jungle,

729.04.text: and tracks which on occasions were seen on the wet ground, beside vegetation which had clearly been bitten into.

746.64.text: The mysterious animal did, however, eventually surface.

755.44.text: The Javan rhinoceros is one of the rarest mammals on earth.

758.96.text: It is slightly smaller than the Indian rhinoceros, and the female either has a very small horn, or none at all.

765.76.text: This has proven to be a blessing, as they are entirely without value for the poachers.

781.04.text: Despite this, they are in serious danger.

783.76.text: At present, Java has the greatest number, but even here there are only 50 individuals.

789.20.text: The rhinoceros had barely stepped from the pages of legend, when it became in danger of extinction.

814.24.text: The rhinoceros is one of the species which arrived in the archipelago during the glaciations, then found themselves cut off.

822.04.text: With the rise in sea-level, only those animals or plants capable of crossing the water were able to reach the islands.

829.08.text: One of these colonised the muds of the estuaries, at the point where the fresh water of the rivers runs into the sea.

836.52.text: These trees form an impenetrable maze of roots and trunks. An intermediate ecosystem which is neither land nor sea.

861.28.text: Conditions here are not the most ideal: the mud is very acid, has little oxygen, and extreme levels of salt.

868.72.text: But the mangrove has the necessary mechanism to overcome these obstacles: its seeds.

880.72.text: The seeds of the mangrove are not only faced with these problems, but must also struggle against tides and currents.

888.16.text: In order to achieve this, they germinate on the tree itself, and develop a stem up to 40 cm long.

895.72.text: Only then do they break off.

902.20.text: If this liberation coincides with low tide, they will cling to the ground and be able to take root.

908.04.text: From then on, the challenge will be to overcome the lack of oxygen.

913.28.text: The trick is to grow long aerial roots, or create vertical tubes, the pneumatophores, which rise up like small breathing pipes.

932.88.text: This seed has fallen during high tide, but it will not die. Its mission is to float off, in search of new territories to colonise.

943.44.text: Below the mangroves, there lies another universe, a world which since ancient times has fascinated and terrified man.

963.80.text: The shallowness of the water, which made possible communication between these islands and the continent

970.68.text: during the Pleistocene era, now means the sea bed is able to receive light and heat.

975.24.text: The marine fauna and flora have here found conditions favourable to life,

980.80.text: and few places in the world can boast of such a profusion of forms.

984.92.text: Here, a single bay may contain twice as many species as the entire Caribbean.

998.20.text: In these submarine paradises, evolution has created beings so different from those of the surface that,

1005.48.text: for many years, scientists were at a loss to explain.

1008.64.text: This clown fish, for example, does not rub against a plant, but rather an anemone, an animal of the polyp family.

1016.48.text: The anemone, with its stinging tentacles, protects the clown fish from its enemies.

1022.80.text: The fish, in return, cleans its protector of parasites.

1036.20.text: Long before science was able to study the symbiotic relationship between the clown fish and the anemone,

1043.16.text: the sea was, for man, a place of countless mysteries. Its depths were unreachable and its fauna, in many case, unknown.

1061.88.text: The lack of scientific information was compensated for by the imagination of man,

1066.56.text: filling the ocean with marine unicorns, giant snakes and mermaids.

1070.80.text: The stories told by the sailors passed from mouth to mouth, feeding people’s imaginations,

1077.28.text: and given further credence by the numbers who dies at sea each year.

1093.84.text: Some of the dangers lying hidden in the waters took the form of multi-coloured fish which possessed weapons capable of killing a man.

1100.52.text: The members of the scorpaenidae family have poisonous barbs on their fins, to dissuade predators from any attempt to hunt them.

1109.72.text: Some of these species, such as the lion fish, are clearly visible, but others camouflage themselves, blending in to the coral background.

1118.80.text: Anyone who makes the mistake of bumping into them will die in just a few hours, never having identified what it was that had attacked them.

1135.96.text: On other occasions, the danger came from much more familiar animals, the snakes.

1149.36.text: Man’s primeval fear of snakes was immediately applied to its marine relatives, and in some cases quite rightly so.

1158.72.text: The olive sea snake is not only swifter than any land serpent, but it also possesses the deadliest poison of any snake in the world.

1183.24.text: As well as fearing the coral reef, man also admired it.

1189.24.text: The clear lagoons of the Indian Ocean make for levels of visibility impossible in other seas.

1194.92.text: On calm days, from the surface it was possible to observe the ecosystem unfolding just a few metres below.

1208.84.text: Before man’s eyes appeared a paradise full of colours, and until then unimagined forms.

1214.64.text: A world in which the fish shared their habitat with animals that looked like plants, such as the holothuroidea (sea cucumbers):

1224.32.text: strange, gigantic worms which seem to expel their digestive system when they are threatened.

1237.20.text: Beneath the surface of the water, man had discovered a world whose mysteries were greater

1243.08.text: even than those of the depths of the Indonesian jungles.

1258.36.text: Beyond the coral reef, lie the open waters of the ocean, one of the environments most feared by man since ancient times.

1264.92.text: The sea bottom is lost in the dark depths, and all that can be seen is the so-called Great Blue, the immensity of the ocean.

1281.84.text: This is a world almost without colour, dominated by the great sea predators, the territory of the most feared ocean animal, the shark.

1300.76.text: Of all the species of shark in the seas, only a few attack man,

1304.88.text: but that has been enough to earn them a reputation inspiring fear and panic.

1315.92.text: Few people are able to tell the difference between these silky sharks and other species of shark, and if in doubt,

1322.52.text: it is best to err on the side of caution, especially if you take into account that the warm waters of the Indian Ocean

1328.44.text: are visited by white sharks, the most dangerous of all.

1332.24.text: In this way, aware or not of their ignorance, men have always considered all sharks to be vicious assassins.

1351.84.text: Above them, on the surface, the mangrove seed floats on its way.

1355.56.text: Its chlorophyll means it can photosynthesise, and so remain alive for almost a year, even though it has germinated.

1362.60.text: If, during this time, it reaches the fresh water of an estuary, it will run aground in the mud,

1371.48.text: grow and create a new mangrove forest on another island of the archipelago.

1381.40.text: And with it, new species of animal life also arrive.

1384.88.text: One of these is scanning the surface through one of its natural periscopes.

1396.92.text: There appears to be no danger. It’s time to come out.

1407.08.text: It is a fiddler crab. It’s name comes from it’s enormous claws, almost equal in size as the rest of its body.

1421.92.text: The mud of the mangrove swamps is a source of food.

1425.84.text: To extract the nutritious substances it contains, the crab scoops it up with its claws, and transfers it to a special organ opposite its mouth.

1434.60.text: These organs are equipped with fine hairs which filter out the food, and then place it in the mouth.

1447.84.text: The mud left behind is accumulated in a small pellet, and then expelled as the crab moves.

1462.32.text: The male can only use one of his claws.

1464.60.text: The other is so big that it is useless for collecting mud. The females don’t have this problem

1477.92.text: This outsized claw serves two basic functions: to mark his territory, and attract the females.

1485.52.text: To do this, the males displays it, with energetic movements.

1504.76.text: When the female approaches his territory, the suitor tries to get close to her, and draw her into his burrow.

1532.36.text: In the end, the females appears to have chosen the other candidate.

1536.64.text: If so, they will remain together until they go to the male’s shelter,

1539.84.text: where they will mate without being disturbed by the other suitors.

1558.00.text: The mangrove forest is home to a number of species of fiddler crabs, but the females have no problem identifying potential mates.

1565.64.text: Each species is of a different colour, and performs a different courting dance, which is just as well with so many suitors together.

1582.12.text: The enormous number of crabs limits the size of their territories, and increases competition.

1587.52.text: It is not rare to see two males at the border between their respective domains fighting for the same female.

1601.48.text: With so many suitors together, it is not long before a fight breaks out.

1613.28.text: During the mating season, these fierce clashes will be often repeated among all the species of crabs that live in the mangrove forest.

1629.72.text: While the crabs get on with their courtship, a tiny animal emerges from the water, supporting itself on its fins.

1636.36.text: It is a fish but, nonetheless, does not die from asphyxiation when it comes out onto dry land.

1652.80.text: The mudskipper is one of the few species of fish in the world capable of living out of the water.

1656.72.text: This amazing ability means it can feed on the tiny algae, crustaceans and worms which live among the mangroves.

1676.36.text: And it comes out of the water not just to get food. Courtship also takes place on land.

1685.16.text: The male shows off his dorsal fin to the females.

1700.20.text: The problem is that the mudskippers are so small they can hardly be seen.

1704.08.text: To compensate, they will have to jump up, or find a slight rise in the level of the mud.

1714.28.text: As they don’t have legs, the mudskippers use their pectoral fins to propel themselves along.

1726.56.text: The fins have acquired strong muscles, and even a joint half way along, reminiscent of the elbow of we land animals.

1745.96.text: To breathe, they use a system similar to the crabs: they retain water in their gills.

1751.08.text: When they ingest food, they have to expel this water, so the mudskippers constantly need to replenish their reserves.

1757.84.text: This also keeps their skin wet, this is very important, because that is another way in which they absorb oxygen.

1785.60.text: Among the thousands of islands that make up the archipelago, there is one which, despite being very small, is of extraordinary value.

1792.48.text: The dangerous reefs which surround it, and its tiny size, meant that for centuries it went entirely unnoticed by the colonisers.

1800.76.text: From its appearance, you would hardly suspect the mysteries it contains.

1813.00.text: At the start of the twentieth century, the island suddenly became the focus of attention.

1817.96.text: The rumour spread that its forests contained fauna which were very different from that which could be seen on its beaches.

1824.60.text: In the interior lived terrible, unknown creatures.

1828.32.text: The stories became increasingly frequent, and the Indonesian government decided to send a scientific expedition.

1835.68.text: What they discovered was so amazing that, in just a few years, the island went from total obscurity to world-wide fame.

1853.08.text: Within the different ecosystems, we will find different species of endemic fauna, as well as others introduced by man.

1860.88.text: Crab-eating macaques and Sunda deer share the island with wild boar, pigs, goats and buffalo.

1869.52.text: All of them, domesticated or wild, are potential prey of the great predator of the island, the animal the natives call “ora”

1892.08.text: The Komodo dragon is the largest living lizard in the world. It can measure 3 metres in length, and weigh 70 kilos

1900.20.text: Some zoologists believe it could be a subspecies of another large lizard which,

1905.64.text: in the past, lived on the continent of Asia, in regions ruled over by the Chinese.

1910.20.text: Perhaps that explains the importance of dragons in their traditions.

1926.76.text: It’s sight and hearing are not very well-developed. To hunt, it relies on smell.

1945.20.text: The dragon has picked up the scent of a deer. The hunt begins.

1958.08.text: Every time it puts out its tongue, the particles carried in the air are trapped on its two tips.

1963.28.text: It then places these tips against a special receptor, called Jacobson’s organ, located at the top of the mouth.

1970.96.text: This analyses the particles and tells the dragon, not only of the presence of the deer, but also in which direction it can be found.

1989.76.text: The deer also has a good sense of smell, and a change in the wind direction alerts it of the presence of the predator.

1999.52.text: The dragon has lost the scent, but it continues to advance, all the time analysing the air.

2005.36.text: Perhaps the wind will bring fresh news of its prey.

2014.32.text: The deer is now beyond its reach, but the lizard does not give up.

2018.92.text: There are many animals in the jungle, and at any time he may perceive the smell of other potential prey.

2024.96.text: Little does he suspect there is one directly above him, watching in silence.

2032.28.text: This one a very close relative.

2057.64.text: Such is the voracity of these animals that the adults do not hesitate to attack the young of the species.

2064.04.text: To avoid being detected, these cover themselves in faeces to disguise their natural smell, and climb up into the trees,

2071.44.text: where they will remain until the predator has moved off.

2083.52.text: As long as they remain in the tree, they will be safe, even if they are detected, despite their olfactory camouflage.

2089.80.text: The adults are too heavy to climb up into the tree after them.

2109.44.text: After his failed attempt at hunting, the dragon heads towards the savanna, drawn by a familiar smell.

2124.44.text: The open spaces are frequented by the large autochthonous herbivores, but also by the domestic cattle of the natives.

2131.92.text: Both find here pasture and shoots on which to feed.

2143.24.text: As payment for the use of the meadows, the inhabitants of Komodo leave the dead bodies of their cattle for the great predator.

2150.60.text: The more deaths there are, the less likely it is the reptiles will collect the debt by attacking the live cattle.

2164.04.text: On this occasion, it is a goat that has died. The wind carries the smell, and the dragon comes to collect its due.

2178.96.text: He must begin to eat immediately. If he has found the corpse, then other dragons will not be far behind.

2186.32.text: The first thing it will eat will be the entrails, which are the softest and easiest parts to eat.

2209.84.text: Before he has had a chance to begin, a second, and even bigger lizard appears on the scene.

2214.52.text: In very little time, the wind has carried the message to all the dragons in the area.

2220.24.text: As if they had been summoned to a meeting, they all come together here in the clearing to take part in the banquet.

2233.32.text: By the time the third guest arrives, the entrails have been devoured.

2238.16.text: This is the prize for the first ones to discover the feast.

2248.80.text: The body is ripped apart and peacefully shared out.

2254.00.text: Surprisingly, they do not fight. Each one finds a space, and concentrates on the meal in front of them.

2270.44.text: In just a few minutes, the goat has almost entirely disappeared.

2274.40.text: The lizards will swallow the bones, the skin, and even the hooves.

2279.32.text: The only thing left lying on the ground are the horns, a pool of blood, and claw marks,

2286.24.text: the only sign that the lizards have accepted the payment of the natives.

2302.68.text: Amid the frenzy, a new character appears in the clearing.

2312.44.text: The pigs were also introduced into the island by man, and are also a feast much appreciated by the dragons.

2318.92.text: Though that does not appear to worry our visitor.

2326.04.text: Despite the proximity, no one attacks him.

2329.48.text: The pig is faster than the lizards, and as long as it knows where they are, it will be safe.

2334.84.text: The predators know this, and will not waste energy trying to hunt it down, when they know it is pointless.

2354.28.text: All the islands on which humans have settled have been invaded by the animals they brought with them.

2360.68.text: The different ecosystems have absorbed pigs, dogs or goats, which escaped from their human masters

2367.04.text: and were able to adapt to life in the wild.

2369.68.text: They are the most recent newcomers, and the latest victims of the Komodo dragon.

2388.44.text: Man has lived alongside the giant lizards since time immemorial.

2393.20.text: Over generations, children and adults who strayed from the settlements have disappeared in the jungle, leaving no trace.

2400.52.text: After the initial anguish, people became resigned to this. It is the tribute they must pay to the dragons for allowing them to live on their island.

2418.28.text: Today, about 2,500 people live on Komodo and Rinca, two of the four islands on which dragons are still exist.

2424.80.text: For them, as for their ancestors, the mystery of Komodo is something entirely normal, which no longer surprises them.

2432.68.text: But for the Europeans who came to these islands for the first time, it was the confirmation that they were indeed in a mythical land,

2439.44.text: where dragons still terrorised man. The animals of their nightmares had come to life.

2460.72.text: Some of these animals remained inactive during daylight hours.

2463.60.text: This group of flying foxes is resting in the branches of the trees, waiting for nightfall.

2467.96.text: They are the largest bats in the world but, despite their threatening appearance, they are inoffensive, because the flying foxes are fruit-eaters.

2494.48.text: It stirs to life just as the day is ending, and the sun goes down.

2511.36.text: With the arrival of night, the islands are transformed.

2515.68.text: The species which remain inactive during the day now awake, the predators go hunting under the cover of darkness,

2521.60.text: and the air is filled with sounds which still today inspire fear among the natives.

2537.60.text: People remain in their huts, and no one leaves the village.

2540.96.text: For a few hours, the islands return to their wild state, untamed by man.

2556.40.text: Though they are a fisher people, the inhabitants of Komodo have transformed the ecosystem of the island.

2562.52.text: Since man first came here, goats and water buffalo have grazed on the savanna.

2567.08.text: The constant felling of trees for wood has cleared many of the forests which, in the past, covered these lands, and much of the islands is now savanna.

2587.28.text: These changes directly affected the dragons.

2590.48.text: Their main prey, the herbivores endemic, were reduced in numbers by the hunters and their trained dogs,

2597.28.text: while the cattle devoured the pasture.

2610.88.text: With the presence of man in its territory, and the decline of its natural prey, confrontation was inevitable.

2617.04.text: The dragons began to hunt down the domestic cattle and came increasingly close to the human settlements.

2629.80.text: As the ecosystems deteriorated, the pressure on the local inhabitants became increasingly great.

2635.56.text: The natives, unaware that they were to blame, saw how each year there were more and more attacks.

2641.72.text: The lizards seemed to collect their tribute ever more frequently.

2660.00.text: The size of the prey is no problem for the lizards.

2663.92.text: If they can’t kill it instantly, biting it will be enough. In their mouths, they have over 50 types of infectious bacteria,

2672.88.text: and a single bite is sufficient for these to be transferred to the wound.

2676.88.text: Within a week at most, the animal will die as a result of the infection.

2683.40.text: When this happens, the dragons will find it by its smell, and quickly devour it.

2689.20.text: A surprising example of planning for the future.

2701.32.text: Neither the tough skin nor the bones are a problem for the powerful jaws of these lizards.

2706.20.text: Anything which provides nutrition will be ingested.

2730.52.text: A dragon can eat up to 70% of its body weight at a single sitting, thanks to its ability to swell its stomach.

2737.08.text: A nine-year old child can be completely devoured by a single adult.

2742.24.text: It is not surprising, therefore, that these creatures inspire profound terror among the natives of the island.

2757.92.text: When they have almost finished, a newcomer joins the banquet.

2763.24.text: It has detected the smell from several kilometres away, and is a little late in arriving.

2768.44.text: Luckily, the dead animal was sufficiently large, and there is still food left for him.

2783.20.text: Their ability to ingest enormous quantities of food at a time allows them to go for long periods without eating.

2790.44.text: They will not find something to eat every day, but nature has given them a stomach able to compensate for this lack of regular meals.

2798.20.text: If we take into account that the species which may have lived in China in the past was even larger,

2805.56.text: the old legends of dragons demanding young virgins to calm their wrath do not seem so exaggerated.

2828.48.text: From the size of their stomachs we can tell which ones are full.

2832.40.text: After having ingested over 40 kg. of food each, they stumble off away from the group.

2855.28.text: The others will shortly follow them. What they want now is a shady place in which to rest and digest.

2870.52.text: Competition between the dragons and man has brought them to the verge of extinction.

2876.00.text: Just four years after they were discovered, they were already a protected species but, despite this, numbers continue to fall.

2882.92.text: It was only 31 years later, in 1936, that the government understood that protecting them

2889.76.text: would be useless if they didn’t also conserve their natural habitat.

2893.80.text: The islands on which they still lived were declared sanctuaries and their ecosystems protected.

2910.44.text: Man finally seems to have understood the value of the jungles which contain plant species found nowhere else in the world,

2916.76.text: the same jungles which gave rise to the most incredible legends.

2929.28.text: The depths of these jungles are the final refuge of the animals which conferred on the islands of Indonesia an aura of mystery.

2936.56.text: Species which, until very recently, have remained hidden from the sight of man,

2942.44.text: and in some cases still today have been little studied by investigators from around the world.

2960.20.text: The archipelago is, at one and the same time, myth and reality, the place where science and fantasy meet.

2967.20.text: The movement of the continental plates created it.

2971.48.text: The glaciations and the sea gave it life, and evolution and isolation have converted it into a legend.

2989.76.text: Today, many of its mysteries have been revealed, but the interior of the islands still hides unknown creatures,

2995.80.text: animals which perhaps today, just like three hundred years ago, we believe only exist in the imagination of our ancestors.
